abstractContent.text: The Columbia Arabic Treebank (CATiB) is a database of syntactic analyses of Ara-bic sentences.
CATiB contrasts with previous approaches to Arabic treebanking in its emphasis on speed with some constraints on linguistic richness.
Two basic ideas inspire the CATiB approach: no annotation of redundant information and using representations and terminology inspired by traditional Arabic syntax.
We describe CATiB's representation and annotation procedure, and report on inter-annotator agreement and speed.

tableCaptions.text: Table 1: Average pairwise IAA accuracies for 5  annotators. The Sents column indicates which  sentences were evaluated, based on token length.  The sizes of the sets are 2.4K (PATB3-Dev) and  3.8K (PROD) tokens.

Table 2: Highest and lowest average pairwise IAA  accuracies for 5 annotators achieved on a single  document -before and after serial annotation. The  "-S" suffix indicates the result after the second an- notation.
